resources.string: Asparagus on Toast with Egg Cream and Cheese
Egg, milk (cream, cheese spread), gluten (toast), nuts

20g of nut oil (or oil with chopped nut inside, ideally hazelnut)
1 bunch asparagus
100 g salad rocket
4 slices rustic bread toast

For the egg sauce
3 eggs
20 g cream (35% milk fat)
1 lemon
Chervil
Salt

For the spiced cheese:
1 g black pepper
1 g white pepper
1 g clove
1 g cardamom
1 g Sichuan pepper
1 g pink pepper
10 g chervil
200 g cream cheese (e.g. quark)

Induction cooktop with temperature control
Bowl
Hand whisk
Using a pestle or a mill, crush the spices and mix with the cheese spread together with the chopped chervil. Put to one side.

Cut the asparagus spears just where the colour starts changing from white to green. Vacuum wrap the green part and cook in a water bath at 85°C for 20 min (if they are very thick they may need a little more time). If not to be eaten immediately, cool them in water with ice and keep in the refrigerator.

Meanwhile, make the egg sauce, by beating the eggs with the cream, a little salt, grated lemon peel and some drops of lemon juice. Place in a bowl and cook with a bain-marie at 85°C (if the bowl is stainless steel) for 10 minutes, stirring constantly. When it takes on a creamy texture, add the chopped chervil, mix and remove from the water bath.
Spread the spiced cheese on the toast, place the warm asparagus on top and dress with the egg sauce. Accompany the recipe with a refreshing salad of rocket and nut oil.
Egg: Immersed in liquid // Vegetables: Sous vide

4 eggs
500 g mashed potato
45 g vegetable sofrito (onions, vegetables and seasoning, lightly fried in oil)
4 baby courgettes
8 green beans
8 spears of green asparagus
4 baby carrots
1 parsnip
4 shallots
Chervil
Chives
Olive oil
Salt
Cook the vegetables sous vide at 85°C for the right amount of time for each one.
Cook the egg in a water bath kept at 65°C for 30 minutes.
Heat up the mashed potato in a bain-marie and the sofrito in a saucepan.
First put the mashed potato on the plate in the shape of a volcano.
Then place the egg in the middle and serve the vegetables, which should have been heated in the microwave for a few seconds or briefly sautéed.
To finish, add a little vegetable sofrito mixed with some mild olive oil, chopped chives, chervil leaves, salt and pepper.
Sous vide salmon with creamy cauliflower purée

4 salmon supremes
1 cauliflower
100 g quinoa
1 carrot
1 leek
1 purple onion
Vegetable stock
200 g of cold brine (10 g of salt per litre of water)
Rosemary or thyme

Induction cooktop with temperature control
Sous-vide cooking bags
Vacuum sealing equipment
Blender
Soak the salmon supremes in the cold brine for 15 minutes. After this time, remove and dry.
Vacuum seal the salmon in a bag and cook in a water bath at 50ºC for 15 minutes. Remove from the bag and place on a hot plate.
Clean the cauliflower and boil in water and salt for at 85º for 45 minutes, or in boiling water for 15 minutes.
Remove from the heat and purée while still hot adding the necessary water or cream to obtain a dense, smooth texture. Keep warm.
Finely cut the vegetables brunoise-style and sauté for 5 minutes. Season,then put to one side.

Cook the quinoa in the boiling vegetable stock for between 20 and 30 minutes. To cook the quinoa in a glass jar, immerse in a water bath at 100ºC for 30 minutes, then cool after cooking and heat again when required for use.
Mix the boiled quinoa with the cooked vegetables
Complement the salmon with the cauliflower purée and the quinoa and vegetable mix then decorate withthyme or rosemary leaves.
Sea Bass with Tomato and Spring Onion Vinaigrette

2 seabass, filleted (4 large fillets) 
200 g ripe tomatoes
2 lettuce hearts
2 cloves of garlic
150 g virgin olive oil
20 g sherry vinegar
Salt and pepper
Rosemary leaves
200 g of brine (100 g of salt per litre of water)

Induction cooktop with temperature control
Sous-vide cooking bags
Vacuum sealing equipment
Put the seabass fillets into very cold brine for 10 minutes.
Dry and vacuum pack. Freeze by placing the fillets very flat in the freezer so that they freeze as quickly as possible.
Separate the leaves of the lettuce hearts. Cut the garlic into thin slices.
Blanch the tomatoes with a small cross-cut on the top. Cool, peel, cut into quarters and remove the watery part. Cut the rest of the tomato into cubes.

In a frying pan, using 50 g of olive oil, fry the sliced garlic for a few minutes until golden. Add the tomato and cook on a mild heat for 3 minutes. Add 100 g of olive oil and 20 grams of sherry vinegar. Add salt and pepper to taste then put to one side.
Prepare a pan with water and add the frozen fish when the water has reached 60ºC and leave to cook for the 8 minutes.
In a frying pan, lightly fry the lettuce heart leaves until golden and set aside.

Optional: after cooking, open the bag and lightly fry the seabass in the frying pan on both sides with a drop of olive oil. If wished, once the seabass is removed from the frying pan, the skin can be gently removed. This step is optional.
Place the fish on a plate, drizzle the tomato vinaigrette over and accompany with the lettuce heart leaves and the rosemary.
Quinoa with vegetables and coconut oil

240 g quinoa
25 g cauliflower
25 g broccoli
25 g carrot
25 g green beans
25 g spring onion
240 g water or frozen vegetable stock
Virgin olive oil
Purple shiso leaves
15 g coconut oil

Induction cooktop with temperature control
Vacuum-sealable bags for cooking
Vacuum sealing equipment
Peel, wash and cut the vegetables in different ways (Julienne, Jardinière, florets ).
Sauté with coconut oil quickly and cool.
Rinse the quinoa twice and leave to soak for 20 minutes.
Drain, dry and toast in a frying pan.
Vacuum-wrap the quinoa, with two parts liquid (water or stock) to one part quinoa and with the sautéed vegetables.
Cook in a water bath at 100º C for 20 minutes.
To serve, season with a few drops of olive oil and decorate with purple shiso leaves or similar.

250 g very ripe strawberries 
125 g sugar
40 raspberries
40 blackberries
30 g sloe berries
40 wild strawberries 
20 g redcurrants 
1 sheet of leaf gelatine (2 g) 
400 g Greek yogurt 
4 sprigs of fresh mint

Induction cooktop with temperature control
Sous-vide cooking bags
Sous-vide equipment
Sieve
Soak the gelatine using cold water.
Cut the strawberries in half and vacuum-seal them in a bag with the sugar.
Put the bag in the water bath to cook at 65º C for 2 hours.
Once the cooking time is completed, sieve the liquid while hot and put the strawberries aside.
Dissolve the gelatine in the resulting juice.
Put 4 strawberries into the bottom of the glass and cover with yogurt. Repeat two or more times.
On the top, arrange the red fruits cut into halves.
Add the strawberry gelatine while still liquid and at room temperature.
Leave to rest until the gelatine sets and decorate with the sprigs of fresh mint.

It is important that the strawberries are very ripe – even if they look a little bit past their best – so that they express all their sweetness and aromas. The prettiest strawberries can be reserved for decorating with the other berries. Remember that the strawberry gelatine must be cold when preparing it to serve.

500 g small milk-caps
200 g mild olive oil
50 g sherry vinegar or similar
salt and pepper

Induction hob with temperature control
Glass jars
Carefully clean the mushrooms using a damp cloth, ensuring they do not lose their aroma.

STEP2 - Option A:
A- To eat straight away.
Briefly blanch the mushrooms in boiling water, drain them and put them in a pot.
Cover with 3 parts olive oil to 1 part vinegar, salt and pepper, and cook on a low heat until they are properly confited.
Remove from the hob and allow to cool in the liquid. They can be served as a side dish or as a main dish with a salad.
Briefly blanch the mushrooms in boiling water, drain them and allow them to cool on a baking tray.
Prepare a mixture of 100 g olive oil and 25 g sherry vinegar or similar, and season with salt and pepper, as well as different herbs and spices if you wish.
Sterilise some glass jars with boiling water, fill with mushrooms and cover with the olive oil and vinegar mixture.
Close the jars and put them in boiling water for 30 minutes.
Leave to cool in the water.
Put them in a cool place or in the fridge and wait 2 weeks before opening.

16 artichokes
80 g Ibérico ham
100 g olive oil
50 g flour
Salt and pepper

Blender
Mandoline
Skimmer
Chopping board
Knives
Saucepan
Baking tray
Kitchen roll
Vacuum pouches
Vacuum sealer
Induction hob with temperature control
Place the artichokes in iced water so that they\'re very cold, to prevent oxidation during preparation.
Clean and peel the artichokes until you\'re left with their hearts.
Cook the artichokes sous vide in two pouches - one with 6 artichokes at 85°C for 90 minutes and the other with 8 artichokes at 85°C for 2 hours. Leave to cool and set aside.
Cut the artichokes from the bag of 6 into quarters and then into eighths.
Blend the artichokes from the bag of 8 in a blender until a fine purée is achieved, and drizzle with 20g of olive oil and a pinch of salt.
Cut the 2 remaining artichokes into slices, toss in flour and fry in plenty of olive oil. Set them aside in a moisture-proof container.
Put the artichoke puree on a plate. Finish with the other 2 types of artichoke. Add the ham. Season with virgin olive oil and a sprinkling of pepper.

1 rack of pork ribs
Olive oil
3 garlic cloves
Bouquet garni
Once confited in olive oil, slow-cook with the garlic and bouquet garni at 80°C for 6/8 hours (check to see if the meat is tender), remove from the hob and leave to cool.

First regenerate in oil or sous vide and place in a pre-heated oven at 220°C coated with some of the oil from the first stage, or finish by grilling the ribs on holm oak charcoals to add smokiness, a crispy outer layer and an intense flavour to the fat which comes into contact with the high temperature.

1 pork jowl (skinned)
1 L brine (100 g salt per 1 L water)
Mild olive oil
2 bok chooy (Chinese cabbage)
40 g gomashio
80 g concentrated meat sauce
Salt and pepper

Vacuum pouches
Vacuum sealer
Induction hob with temperature control
Immerse the jowl in brine for 1 hour. Dry and vacuum-seal.
Cook in a water bath at 65ºC for 18 hours. Then cool in an ice bath.
Slice the bok choy, vacuum-seal and cook in a water bath at 85ºC for 20 minutes.
Sear the pork jowl in a frying pan on medium to low heat until it turns brown, releases excess fat, and takes on a crispy texture.
Sear the bok choy in a frying pan at medium heat.
Pour a little hot meat sauce onto the plate and place two slices of pork jowl on top of it. Add a little fleur de sel, pepper, and olive oil.
Place the bok choy beside the pork jowl and sprinkle a little gomashio on top.

For the asparagus
20 medium-size white asparagus

For the citrus fruit mayonnaise
300 g sunflower oil
2 egg yolks
Salt
1 lemon
1 mandarin nad/or orange and/or grapefruit

To garnish
Segments of orange and/or mandarin and/or grapefruit
Lemon balm

Induction hob with temperature control
Cooking pouches
Reduce the juice from the citrus fruit by cooking it on a very low heat until it has been reduced to a quarter of its volume (when cold, it should have a slightly dense texture). Leave to cool.
We will then make the mayonnaise with the egg yolks and the sunflower oil.
Add 3/4 parts of the reduction from the citrus fruit juice, mix with a blender and season with salt.
Peel the asparagus with a peeler removing all the hard fibre.
Cook in a water bath at 85ºC for 45 minutes.
Refresh in an ice bath and set aside.
Place the asparagus on a plate, cover with the mayonnaise and flambé with a blowtorch until it is slightly glazed.
Garnish with segments of mandarin orange, orange or grapefruit, lemon balm leaves and a few drops of citrus fruit reduction.
Chicken breast with apricots and olives

For the chicken
4 chicken breasts of 220 g, with their skins
1 L brine (100 g salt per 1 L water)
Sichuan pepper

For the olive sauce
100 g black olives
1 glass rancio wine
750 g poultry broth

For the apricot purée
200 g ripe apricots

Colander
Saucepan
Hand blender
Vacuum pouches
Vacuum sealer
Induction hob with temperature control
Place the chicken in the brine for 1 hour. Dry and vacuum-seal with a little Sichuan pepper.
Cook in water at 65°C for 40 minutes. Or in the oven at 120°C for 35 minutes (the aim is for the centre to reach 65°C in both cases)
Open the bag and sear the chicken with a little oil (about 2 minutes for the skin side on low heat and 30 seconds for the meat side).
Boil the rancio wine and the poultry broth
Reduce until a quarter remains. Strain.
Add the pitted black olives, blend, and pass through a conical strainer.
If necessary, achieve the desired texture using xanthan gum (proportion: 3g/l) and season with salt.
Peel the apricots and remove their stones.
Vacuum-seal and cook at 85ºC for 20 minutes. Or in the oven at 120°C for 60 minutes.
Arrange the apricot purée, interspersed with the thickly sliced chicken and finish with the olive sauce.
Thyme soup with low- temperature egg

1 bunch thyme
100 g olive oil
1 L of water or chicken broth
8 thin slices of dry bread
2 cloves garlic
4 organic chicken eggs (small)
Finely sliced toast
Salt and pepper
Lightly fry the two garlic cloves in a saucepan.
Add the thyme, tied toghether so that it doesn\'t crumble, moisten with water or broth and cook for 10 minutes on low heat. Then remove the thyme and garlic.
Add the dry toasted bread and leave to cook for 6 to 8 minutes. Then blend or whisk.

Put the soup in a bowl and add an egg, cooking at a low temperature (65°C for between 20-40 minutes, depending on the size and desired consistency, as when cooked at a higher temperature, the yolk will be harder).
Season with some salt, pepper and thyme flowers.
Decorate with olive oil and toast.

For the sirloin
0,8 Kg cleaned sirloin setak
3 spoonfuls of whisky
Sichuan pepper
1 L brine (100 g salt per 1 L water)

For the garnish
Leek
Carrot
Courgette
Green asparagus
Shallot

For the pine nut oil
100 g olive oil
50 g pine nuts
Salt

To finish and serve
100 g beef juice

Frying pan
Vacuum pouches
Vacuum sealer
Induction hob with temperature control
Place the sirloin in brine for 15 minutes. Dry.
Vacuum seal the meat in a pouch with ice cubes made from whisky. The ice cubes allow the pouch to be sealed properly.
Cook in a water bath at 65°C for 15 minutes or at 55°C for 20 minutes. Or in the oven at 70°C for 20 minutes.
Cut and blanch the vegetables, or cook them sous vide or in boiling water.
Brown the halved pine nuts in olive oil over very low heat.
Once roasted and cooled, add the rest of the oil, salt and pepper.
Remove the sirloin from the bag and sear quickly in a frying pan on high heat for a very short period of time to prevent it drying out.

Deglaze* the frying pan with the leftover juice from the pouch (*Deglaze: to add wine or a similar liquid to a frying pan or baking tray in order to obtain the fat or juice which is left over after cooking). Add the beef sauce and cook for 1 minute. Remove and strain if necessary.
Plate the sirloin with the vegetables, add the sauce and drizzle with pine nut oil.

The cooking time can be adjusted tu suit you personal taste. If fairly rare sirloin is preferred, the cooking time at 65ºC can be reduced to 12 minutes, and conversely, if well-done meat is preferred, it can be extended to 18 minutes.

Cod with spinach,
raisins, pine nuts
and Idiazabal
cheese
Cod with spinach, raisins, pine nuts and Idiazabal cheese

600 g cod
200 g olive oil
400 g fresh spinach
60 g raisins
20 g pine nuts
25 g Idiazabal cheese
25 g liquid cream
50 g Pedro Ximenez
Fresh chives

Reduce the Pedro Ximenez on a low heat until you have a reduction. Remember that when it is hot, you cannot tell if it has thickened, so allow it to cool and then check to avoid it being cooked for too long or burning.
Melt the cheese with the cream on a low heat and set aside.
Chop the chives and mix with a few drops of virgin olive oil.
Heat the olive oil to 50°C, add the cod and cook for 15 minutes at this temperature, ensuring it remains constant. Or in the oven at 70°C for 15 minutes.
Sauté the pine nuts and raisins in a frying pan, add the fresh spinach leaves and sauté for a few seconds.
Place the spinach in the middle of the plate. Add a piece of cod confit, as well as some cheese sauce, Pedro Ximenez reduction and a few drops of olive oil.

4 entrecotes 400 g
1 l brine (1 l water per 100 g salt)
4 tender carrots
50 g butter
30 g sunflower oil
4 sprigs of rosemary and 4 sprigs of thyme
4 cloves of garlic
Spinach

Induction cooktop with temperature control 
Sous-vide cooking bags
Vacuum equipment
Put the entrecôte in the brine for 1 hour.
Clean the carrots and potatoes and vacuum seal them in pouches. Cook at 85°C for 30 minutes. Or in the oven at 160°C for 40 minutes. Leave to cool and set aside.
After one hour, remove the entrecôte from the brine, dry it and quickly sear it in a frying pan with some olive oil.
After searing the meat, leave to cool and then vacuum seal it in a pouch with a sprig of rosemary and thyme, and a garlic clove.
Cook the entrecôte in a water bath at 55°C for 1 hour. Or in the oven at 65°C for 60 minutes.
Then remove it from the pouch and sear it in a hot frying pan with the butter and 15 g of sunflower oil.
Lightly sauté the carrots and potatoes, which should have been preheated in a water bath at 85°C and cut into uniform pieces, with a little butter and 15 g of sunflower oil.
Season the entrecôte, carrots and potatoes with salt and pepper, and serve.

4 hake supremes (125 g each)
2 potatoes
2 onions
200 g sunflower oil
200 g olive oil
6 garlic gloves
Fresh rosemary
25 g red wine vinegar or balsamic vinegar
Salt
Spring onion
Cut the onion into julienne strips and cook slowly in a pot on a low heat until it is fully done and has a caramelised appearance.

Prepare the rosemary vinaigrette by frying the slices of garlic in a frying pan with some olive oil and when they begin to turn a light brown colour, add the rosemary. Remove from the hob and when the olive oil is warm, add the vinegar and season with salt and pepper.
Peel the potatoes, cut them into slices and confit them in the oven or on the hob on a low heat until they are soft.

Season the hake supremes with salt and pepper, sear both sides in a frying pan on a high heat, place on a baking tray with a spoonful of vinaigrette and cook for between 12-16 minutes at 65°C. Or in the oven at 90°C for 20 minutes. When the hake is done, it should be slightly firm when you press down on it, or be between 50-55°C in the centre when checked using a thermometer.
Heat up the slices of potato and onion confit.
Put it on a plate as a garnish, add a piece of hake, pour over the garlic and rosemary vinaigrette and decorate with slices of spring onion and fresh rosemary.
Chocolate Cream with Hazelnut Praline and Macadamia Nuts
Milk, egg, nuts and dried fruits.

275 g milk
325 g cream
130 g egg yolk
40 g sugar
50 g chocolate topping
Hazelnut praline
Macadamia nuts
20 g stone-ground chocolate

Induction cooktop with temperature control
Hand-held blender
Hand whisks
Glass jars
Sieve
Grater
Put the milk and cream in the pan and heat to 85°C. Remove from the hob, add the chocolate and blend using an electric hand blender. Leave to cool slightly.
In a bowl, mix the sugar and egg yolks.
Strain the chocolate mixture on to the egg yolks and mix. Leave to rest until the foam has disappeared.
Fill the glass jars with the mixture up to the top, put the lids on them and cook for 60 minutes at 85°C. Or in the oven at 100°C for 60 minutes.
Then allow to reach room temperature and, after a few minutes, cool with water and ice.
When the mixture has set, top with a little hazelnut praline, as well as the grated macadamia nuts and unrefined chocolate.

For the bacon
400 g slab of bacon with rind 
400 g water
125 g soy sauce
75 g leek
75 g onion
1/2 cinnamon stick
5 g ground pepper
25 g brown sugar

For the sandwich
1/4 cucumber
1/2 onion
Salt
4 ciabatta rolls
In a pan place the onion and the leek cut into mirepoix (large, irregular cubes).
Add the water, the whole piece of slab bacon, the soy sauce and the spices.
Cook at 90°C for 3 h, covering it to avoid it drying out. Or in the oven at 120°C for 4h.
Once the cooking time is up, separate the meat from the vegetables and strain.
Reduce the resulting juice until a dense sauce is obtained and strain once more.
Cut the cucumber into half-moons and the onion julienne-style, mix and season to taste.
Cut the bacon slab into 1/2 cm thick slices and heat with the reduced sauce.
Assemble the sandwich arranging a layer of raw vegetables on the bread with the bacon on top. To finish, add a little more sauce.
